Samuel and in this episode episode 51
I'm going to talk about
isovolumetric contraction so let's get
right into it now what we're looking at
here is diastole at the top and systole
at the bottom so this is where the
ventricles are relaxing and this is
where the ventricles are contracting and
as you can see blood is flowing into the
atria and then into the ventricles and
then when the ventricle contracts that
pushes the blood into the aorta so that
it can go to the rest of the body and it
also sends blood to the lungs
now there's something very significant
that's happening here when the blood
comes in you can see this atrial
ventricular valve is open to let that
blood get into the ventricle then once
the ventricles contract that causes this
atrial ventricular valve to close and of
course the same thing over here so that
the blood does not flow back into the
atrium now you see here that this
semilunar valve is open however that
does not happen immediately when the
ventricle contracts it needs to build up
enough pressure to open that valve so
that the blood can flow out of the
ventricle and to the rest of the body so
what we're going to look at over here is
what we've looked at before where right
after the ventricular contraction
happens the cycle starts over and the
ventricle fills with blood so you're
going to see an increased volume in the
ventricle and then at a certain point
the atria are going to contract so when
the right atrium contracts that forces
even more blood faster into the
ventricle so when the left atrium
contracts that force is more
blood faster into the left ventricle and
then the ventricle contracts and when it
contracts that is going to push blood
out of the ventricle and it's going to
go to the rest of the body this is the
end diastolic volume here and here we
have the end systolic volume now let's
look at what's happening in the
ventricle when it comes to pressure
during the relaxation period the
diastole we're not going to have any
pressure in the ventricle so we hardly
have any so I'm going to put that around
zero and then at a certain point let's
say at this point here we have the
atrium contracting and when the atrium
contracts that's going to cause an
increase in pressure in the ventricle
not a huge increase but an increase
nonetheless and then the ventricle is
going to contract now when the ventricle
contracts that's going to cause an
increase in pressure in the ventricle so
let me draw that here so here we have
that increase in pressure but as you can
see it's not until we reach this point
that the valve actually opens the
semilunar valve opens so that the blood
can flow out so this is the point that
we need to reach and let's say that that
point is somewhere around 80 millimeters
of mercury so the pressure has to reach
approximately 80 when that happens the
semilunar valves open and the blood gets
ejected so we still have some increase
in pressure and then at a certain point
the muscle relaxes we get diastole and
the pressure comes back down now this
time period between where the ventricle
contracts but the blood does not get
ejected and this point we call this let
me do that in a different color
we call this
I so volumetric contraction why do we
call it isovolumetric contraction iso
refers to the fact that it's the same
volumetric refers to volume so the
volume stays the same contraction
because the ventricle is actually
contracting even though the volume is
staying the same and the reason the
volume is staying the same is because
the valves are closed so the blood
cannot leave until it reaches that point
where the semilunar valve opens and once
that opens the blood can flow out to the
rest of the body that's it that's the
concept of isovolumetric contraction and
